comment.narrative: - Cooperation with Nepal project on embroidered processing has been well conducted to share the results and experience on community-driven development, poverty alleviation, women’s empowerment and cultural heritage. - A fourteen-day e-business training course was held in Chuxiong, attracting nearly 40 embroidery women from three project sites in Chuxiong Yi embroidery associations. - From 24-29 October 2015, Professor Shengkun Zhou, an expert in China rural development field, conducted field visit, assessment of experts and face-to-face conversation with representatives from pilot sites to understand project implementation process and existing problems. - 70 embroidery women in Yongren County received cycling capital 240,000 in total, ranging from 2000 to 50,000 respectively. Over 20 products in 5 kinds have been invented because of the investment on market expansion. The income has raised from 50,000 to 200,000 due to the increasing retail outlets. The implementation of Mother Entrepreneurship Project has encouraged the beneficiaries of this project to start up business. Over 1200 people have participated in the embroidery development, creating over 3 million economic profits with an average increased income 1500.

- Disseminate and promote project results; - Set up a SSC project with Nepal CO in fundraising for the Nepalese earthquake victims through Yi-Nepal initiative by selling the cross-over products made by Yi and Nepal communities.

- The new component of the Project, the Nepal part has been implemented through UNDP Nepal Office. The component aims to support the development of micro and small enterprises in Nepal. - A collection of cross-culture artisan products combing Yi embroidery from Yongren Country of Yunnan Province and Pashmina from Nepal was launched at Shanghai Fashion Show. The theme of this event was “Lost Reappear”. It aims to create an opportunity for community-to-community based empowerment and enable participants from Nepal and Yi Minority to explore their different traditions and learn from each other to support low-income women entrepreneurs. Senior representatives from China Women’s Development Foundation (CWDF), Mary Kay, UNDP, Deputy Director, Shanghai Municipal Commission of Commerce, and Ministry of Industry of Nepali government participated in press conference of the launch.

-Transformation of government functions through Clarification of public sector functions, responsibilities and powers -Restructuring the government administrative system through Improved operation of ‘superministries’ -Streamlining administrative operations through simplification of processes for improved service delivery -Reform of Public Service Units (PSUs) through classification of PSUs and establishment of an effective regulatory framework

- Four research projects were conducted to support key reform initiatives in public sectors, including establishing the sytem of government power list at different levels, improving administrative environmental supervision system, streamlining administration and delegating power, etc - The oversea training delegation to United States is organized on the effective government regulation of the market. . In addition, a delegation of the China Society for Public Sector Reform is organized to Brazil to attend the annual meeting of the International Institute of Administrative Sciences to enhance theoretical exchange in the public sector reform. - information communication capacity was strenghthend in underdeveloped regions.

title.narrative: Strengthen Capacity of Poverty Reduction Centre (IPRCC)

description.narrative: Strengthening the capacity of the International Poverty Reduction Center in China for South-South Cooperation

Through the project, the International Poverty Reduction Center in China's institutional development will be further strengthened and South-South cooperation for poverty reduction of other developing countries promoted.
capital of a political entity

Indicators 1. IPRCC seen by end of project as a global knowledge hub for consistent information, knowledge and training on income and human poverty reduction. Training packages, currently produced on an ad hoc basis are professionalized and systematized and feedback on training regularly assessed. A set of core elements for training courses developed. Quality of publications and research meet higher international standards verified by international advisory board. At least 50% of documents and publications translated into English. On line training is available and accessed by at least 5 countries. At least 10 staff per year sent overseas for international exposure to training/study tours, conferences, research and knowledge sharing. A lasting human resource development strategy and internal capacity building master plan defined and applied. 2. Center’s activities strategically linked to a network of poverty and development focused national and international institutions and IPRCC trainee alumni and well integrated into relevant global knowledge networks; Increased opportunities for real and/or virtual dialogue and debate on pro-poor policy issues generated through annual forums with international media coverage beyond China, workshops and other active dissemination, publication and communication in China and cross recipient countries. At least 200 individuals from at least 20 developing countries in Asia and the Pacific region, Latin America and Africa and 200 individuals from China representing a cross-section of government and non-governmental institutions receive tailored training on poverty reduction and pro-poor development strategies and lessons. Gender equality is addressed in training contents, trainer and trainee as well as other beneficiary composition. IPRCC hosts at least two full-time research fellows (one international) and two short-term visiting scholars per year, one national research/training manager or coordinator.

comment.narrative:
1. Limited institutional and management capacity to accommodate demand from other developing economies to learn from China’s experience of poverty reduction and systemize training responses; limited capacity with respect to knowledge management, publication of research and sharing of experience and knowledge on poverty reduction and meeting the MDGs; Translation capacities are poor. Lessons on China’s poverty reduction related information, research and field experience scattered among national institutions. Lack of systemic knowledge of developing country situations and needs. Disconnection between poverty-focused applied research, needs-based training, pro-poor policy formulation and implementation
2. Formal linkages with other research institutions and think tanks not well established for purposes of exchange of experience and lessons and with limited sharing and collaboration across institutions and countries. Mechanisms for South-South cooperation not formalized either with institution or government. Limited knowledge and understanding of recipient countries about China’s experiences and in poverty reduction, needs for addressing multiple dimensions of poverty and better understanding of poverty-reduction impacts of macro-policies for pro-poor policy design and implementation; Strategic linkages between targeted, regional and macro level interventions in China and recipient countries not in place

1. Exchanges trainings benefited to other developing countries in sharing China’s development experience. And Knowledge products, such as studies on selected topics relating to poverty reduction and social development, produced and disseminated during the forums and seminar. IPRCC capacity building needs assessed and addressed through staff exchange programme. 2. High level dialogues and regional forums organized to promote poverty reduction and inclusive development, such as International Poverty Reduction Forum, China-ASEAN Forum, China-Africa Conference. Strengthened partnerships with research institutes and international organizations.

1. a delegation composed of 4 staff from 4 divisions (general affairs, finance, international exchanges, cooperation and training) of IPRCC were sent to ’South Africa to strengthen cooperation between China and Africa; through this activity, both the institutional capacity and the staff capability have been significantly improved. 18 issues of International Poverty Reduction Briefing, 7 research contracted to carry out applied researches. IPRCC renewed contracts with 3 technical officers, 1 legal advisor and 2 UN Volunteers, and renewed contract with 1 post-doctoral fellow. 2. In 2015, three high-level international events were successfully held. Especially "the International Poverty Eradication Day Event" was held and raised public awareness on public involvement in poverty reduction. The 9th China-ASEAN Forum on Social Development and Poverty Reduction was convened in Laos with a strong support from the Laos government. The 6th Africa-China Poverty Reduction and Development Conference was held in South Africa with strong support from UNDP. The conference is themed as Towards Post-2015 Africa-China Sustainable Co-operation on Poverty Reduction and Development which signifies China’s strong support to poverty reduction exchange and cooperation between China and African countries. Also this year the Conference has been included into the FOCAC framework as one sub-forum of the FOCAC Summit in South Africa. In total 670 participants attended the forum.

1. Exchanges training benefited to other developing countries in sharing China’s development experience. And Knowledge products, such as studies on selected topics relating to poverty reduction and social development, produced and disseminated during the forums and seminar. IPRCC capacity building needs assessed and addressed through staff exchange programme. 2. High level dialogues and regional forums organized to promote poverty reduction and inclusive development, such as International Poverty Reduction Forum, China-ASEAN Forum, China-Africa Conference. Strengthened partnerships with research institutes and international organizations.

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration

- Coordination of relevant government divisions, research institutes and private stakeholders strengthened; - Two Internet-based Farmers Service and Training Centres built to enhance the agriculture extension capability; - Increased awareness, in both public and private sectors, of the social, economical and ecological benefits of effective sand control, responsible use of soil and water resources and self-motivated sustainable development. - Established a market-lead value-added fruits and vegetable production industry, characterized by organic production and low carbon emissions. - A 5-year watershed management master plan developed to include the grass land, water courses, forests, farms and road system into one integrated ecological and social-economic zone. - Real-life demonstration regions with regenerated ecosystems and improved livelihood - Successful practices to other part of China and the rest of the world.

comment.narrative: N/A

- Training 940 peasants migrating from the South Region of Ningxia on red raspberry cultivation techniques for livelihood improvement in Yueyahu eco-resettlement pilot area. - Training sessions for 1,370 peasants and technicians in Yanchi pilot area, Zhongwei pilot area, Yueyahu resettlement area, bring about the peasants income rising from 10 villages around local pilot areas. - By activities such as tri-party review meeting, actively co-operating with auditing department and customs office, daily routine communicating vertically and horizontally with CICETE and UNDP, local government officers, participatory sectors and stakeholders from pilot areas , project implement government agency, local cooperating agency on the project advancing issues, the monitoring work is more efficient, the concept of UNDP program is got access to the stakeholders’ minds. - By organizing groups by 6 personals from Zhongwei pilot area to visit Shandong, Shanxi and Hebei province for learning the experience and lessons on castor planting and marketing issues, Ouli new species introduction, the new style and new model of Ouli grafting. - From Aug.11th-13nd, carrying on the program management personals training session with ability building-up so as to improve the intercommunication between pilots area personals for exchanging the ideas and knowledge each other, 50 personals involved. - Because of successful extending of Ouli Planting, enterprises took part in the Ouli productivity actively, signing the planting and sale contact with local peasants in pilot area, holding the Ouli exhibition in Ningxia International Convention and Exhibition Center, Zhongwi Gaiguo-Ouli Festival. Bringing about the influence in Zhongwei pilot area, Zhongwei government support the activities of Ouli productivity, took it as the alternative plant in old-gravel field in Zhongwei XIangshan pilot. - Continuing in purchasing agricultural machinery for the pilot area. Coordinating the relationships togeth

Wildlife and Nature Reserve Management Bureau of Qinghai Forestry Department thought that the provincial PAs Development Plan 20112020 has covered with more representatives of ecoregion and vegetation types in which some targets have been achieved Instead they prefer to develop Qinghai PA monitoring plan which is consistence with State Forestry Administrations funding strategy and the strengthening of PAs management effectiveness is one of GEF projects priorities In terms of this consideration GEF sponsored the development of Qinghai PA monitoring plan and PMO asked a specialist to conduct a mapping analysis between vegetations and existing PAs in 2015 which indicates the representatives of vegetations and ecoregions in Qinghai and gaps of PAs coverage and also includes the recommendations to future PA system planning

comment.narrative: - In the first quarter of 2015, the PMO completed the selection of the project contracting units, four units selected as the subject of cooperation units. - The international policies research report and national policies evaluation report on biomass pellets replacing fossil fuel technology application was revised. - Research report through domestic study tours on application of biomass pellets in China in terms of technology, business model, market demand and emission standards was completed. - Formulation of pilot sites selection principles and standards, identification of six pilot sites under license from the national PMO, establishment of seventeen pilots in accordance with the above pilot sites in pilot site selection criteria meeting on 28th April and 22th May in Beijing. - Research on EMC-based business models of the pilots was carried out; - 3 meetings were held in 2015 for the purpose of documentation and dissemination of best practices in applying the emission standards and monitoring methodologies to the pilots; - One ME meeting was held at the end of 2015.

description.narrative: first-order administrative division
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Number of communities and people who participate in the assessment 2. Statistics tables 3. Assessment report 4. Evaluation reports 5. Training manuals 6. Number of communities 7. Number of trainees 8. Feedback from the trainees 9. Evaluation plan 10. Compeletency of Evaluation report 11.Compeletency of Mission report 12. Project report 13. Quarterly and annual reports 14. Policy research report

comment.narrative: On 20 April 2013, a 7-magnitude earthquake hit the Lushan County of Ya’an City in Sichuan Province. As of 23 April, 193 people have reported dead, 25 still missing and 12,211 injured. 1.99 million people in total of 115 counties have been affected. As of 23 April, 3,509 aftershocks were recorded and at least 100 aftershocks were 3.0 magnitudes and above. Over 99% of houses in the epicenter, Longmen Township of Lushan County collapsed, and local infrastructure were badly damaged. Shortly after the earthquake, UN Resident Coordinator in China extended her condolences and offered UN support to the Government of China. On 21 April, UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon expressed his deepest sympathies to Chinese government and people. He pledged “the UN is ready to provide assistance and to mobilize any international support that may be needed”. UN agencies are in coordination with their line government agencies and collating information on damage and loss. To support the UN in joining relief activities, Bureau for Crisis Prevention and Recovery (BCPR) has approved USD 100,000 from the Immediate Response Category (II) of TRAC 1.1.3. The fund will be utilized to reinforce the coordination efforts and needs assessments. The Government of China is mounting all-out efforts in rescuing affected people and allocating life-saving materials to the areas. On July 20, Sichuan Provincial Government officially released 11 plans on post-disaster reconstruction including strategy of integrating disaster reduction during the phase of early recovery. Ya’an earthquake struck the same area where people had experienced the devastating Wenchuan earthquake in 2008. While the Government is putting all efforts in saving lives and assessing the casualties and economic losses, the absence of needs-based impact assessment in the overall post-disaster evaluation may lead to incomplete pictures and overlook the real needs behind the physical damage and loss. Therefore it is important for UNDP

Develop and refine a project implementation work plan; Set up working groups and expert groups;Conduct a field research assessing the disaster risk reduction and preparedness capacity of the severely earthquake-stricken townships and villages in Ludian County in the course of post-earthquake recovery and reconstruction;Write research report and publish in related journals;Design training courses; Organize training in Yunnan Province (2-day personnel training on the disaster information management in Ludian and earthquake-affected areas); Prepare for the evaluaiton ;Mid-term evaluation ;Final evaluation ; Summarization and dissemination ;Project management of National Disaster Reduction Centre of China (NDRCC); International DRR Day activity;Policy research on Disaster reconstruction under the Sendai Framework;Recruit a national consultant.

Identify needs assessment methodologies and develop needs assessment questionnaires and prepare for interviews;Conduct need assessment in the communities; Design training courses of community disaster reduction and mitigation;Organize trainings at Lushan;Design household emergency kit;Coordinate, implement and manage according to project work plan ;Submit quarterly and annual reports and financial reports (Chinese/English);Conduct evaluation and review ;Recruit a Programme Manager

In the beginning of 2015 two major awarenessraising events were cohosted by the project with Hainan Forestry Department which is the celebration of World Wetland Day in Feburary and the BirdLoving Week and the World Wildlife Day in March According to official statistics in total 25 thousand visitors attended the two events which mostly were urban residents students from primary and middle school government officials NGOs etc

description.narrative: Establishment of a suitable crosssectoral body at provincial level to facilitate mainstreaming of wetland conservation into sectoral policies plans and practices

comment.narrative: Coordination between wetland PA subsystem management and development planning and sectoral planning occurs but is largely responsive and ad hoc

A permanent crosssectoral body is established at provincial level formally recognized by all sectors and proactively promoting and facilitating strategic intersectoral coordination on wetland conservation

To promote cross sectoral cooperation and the wetland mainstreaming the project has encouraged and invited relevant government officials to visit project sites and participate in project activities Moreover crosssectoral meetings and training workshops with relevant local government agencies including environment water resources tourism marine and fishery forestry were organized in Wenchang Dongfang Danzhou Sanya Such meetings are proved to be effective and influential as the government official can i learn about the project ii have some technical capacity building part to it iii also facilitate sharing and mutual learning
To establish a specialized crosssectoral body on wetland conservation is perceived to be of little chance because there are already many such bodies on different issues which are mainly related to a specific national project of significance So that during the 2nd PSC meeting it was approved that the crosssectoral body will be built on the current PSC by trying to include more government departments

description.narrative: Improved data sharing platform for Hainans wetland PAs is established regularly updated and in frequent use by a range of data providers and target audiences

comment.narrative: Data on Hainans wetland PAs are dispersed largely unavailable online and not regularly updated
A centralized database on Hainans wetland PAs is accessible to online users updated on a monthly basis and registers at least 100 hits per month

To develop an online database platform the Project contracted the Network Research Development Dept NRDD of Research Institute of Forest Resource Information Techniques under Chinese Academy of Forestry After several rounds of discussion together with the NR management and NRDD the content of the database was formulated and the first draft of the database platform is foreseen in Sept 2015

description.narrative: Key development and sectoral plans such as the 13th 5year plan and subsidiary plans for key sectors include explicit reference to conservation of the Mangrove PA Network

comment.narrative: 12th 5year plan and subsidiary plans for tourism fisheries water resources and other key sectors do not adequately address wetland conservation

13th 5year plan and subsidiary plans for tourism including the Hainan International Tourism Island Master Plan fisheries water resources and other key sectors include explicit reference to conservation of the Mangrove PA Network

To promote wetland mainstreaming the project encouraged and invited relevant government officials to visit project sites and participate in project activities Moreover crosssectoral meetings with relevant local government agencies including environment water resources tourism marine and fishery forestry were organized in Wenchang Dongfang and Sanya during the CTA visit in Hainan Such meetings are proved to be effective and influential as the government official can i learn about the project ii have some technical capacity building part to it iii also facilitate sharing and learning amongst each other

description.narrative: Sector specific standards for tourism and coastal fisheries are consistent with international standards for responsible ecotourism and fishery practices

comment.narrative: Existing plans and practices for key sectors including tourism and fishery development do not adequately address key issues for wetland PAs

Approval and demonstrated voluntary uptake of sector specific standards for tourism by 20 companies based on ecotourism category of the ASEAN Tourism Standards and coastal fisheries by 2 villages based on the FAO Code of Conduct for Responsible Fisheries and related guidelines

The project had contacted Haikou Tourism Development Committee to get the draft Regulation on the Management of Mangrove and Rural Tourism Zone Further study is to be made to look into the existing regulations and plans

description.narrative: Improved protection and management of Hainans ecosystems through expansion consolidation and sustainable financing of the provincial PA system
Financing Plan for the expanded PA system under Hainan Master Plan for the PA System including strategy and action plan for the wetland PA subsystem

comment.narrative: Master Plan for Hainan PA System awaiting approval no financing plan
Financing Plan approved for the expanded PA system under Hainan Master Plan for the PA System including strategy and action plan for the wetland PA subsystem

The Master Plan for Hainan Nature Reserves Development is still under elaboration which is led by the Hainan Environment Protection Department formerly the Hainan Land Environment and Resources Department Besides based on the result of 2nd national wetland inventory the master plan for Hainan wetland conservation is now under elaboration The financial plan for the wetland PA subsystem will be developed afterwards

description.narrative: Increase in the number of wintering Blackfaced Spoonbills Platalea minor in Hainan

comment.narrative: Wintering population of 76 BF Spoonbills
Wintering population of 100 BF Spoonbills with a stable or increasing trend

According to the result of the International Blackfaced Spoonbill Census in every January the number in Hainan slightly increased from 44 in 2012 to 56 in 2015
In Aug 2014 the local government planted about 573ha of mangrove seedling on the mudflat and beach inside the NR for the purpose of restoring mangrove forest and attracting more BF spoonbill However according to bird specialists the planting efforts may have a negative impact So based on the specialists advice and previous studies on BF spoonbill the project wrote an advice letter to the local government In addition during CTAs visits to Dongfang this issue was openly discussed among the government officials Now the government was highly aware of the problem and willing to take measures to make change

During the inception workshop the target of 1000 ha for mangrove replanting was perceived to be unrealistic because the available land in NRs are very limited So it was proposed to change the wording of mangrove replanting into mangrove wetland restoration However the approval procedure of this revision is not completed So this issue will be rediscussed and confirmed during the next PSC meeting by end of 2015 before asking for approval by UNDP regional office
Moreover during the project implementation it was found that the government stressed too much on mangrove replanting instead of restoring the ecosystem service functions of mangrove wetland Even worse fastgrowing exotic mangrove species were commonly used in the replanting To resolve the problem in March 2014 the project organized a mangrove restoration expert discussion workshop at the provincial level and in May and June 4 trainings were conducted for officials from different government apartments in Sanya Danzhou Dongfang and Wenchang
So far the replanting area for selected sites are
Dongzhaigang NNR 1333ha finished
Qinglanggang PNR 533ha ongoing
Xinying NWP 8 ha ongoing
Dongfang PNR 573ha finished
Sanya CNR 367ha ongoing
Total 2886ha

description.narrative:
Increased protection status of selected wetland related reserves taking full account of access and benefit sharing rights of indigenous minority ethnic group stakeholders
Yinggeling is a forested catchment area for Haikou area

comment.narrative:
1 Yinggeling PNR 50464 ha
2 Fanjia PNR gt5000 ha
3 Haiwei Prov Wetland Park c300 ha
4 Sanya City NR 728ha

1 Yinggeling PNR becomes NNR
2 Fanjia PNR becomes NNR
3 Haiwei Prov Wetland Park becomes NWP
4 Sanya City NR becomes PNR

During the inception workshop the baseline and target of this indicator was discussed and proposed to be changed The proposed change were as below
1 change the listed Haiwei WPnot yet a Provincial WP to Dongfang PNR and its baseline level is PNR and the target is NNR
2 change the target for Fanjia PNR to the demonstration PNR of wetland type
3 change the target for Sanya CNR to demonstration CNR
For the baseline the Haiwei Wetland Park is not yet a provincial park During the inception workshop this problem was discussed and proposed to change to Dongfang PNR of which the baseline level is PNR and the target is NNR However the approval procedure of this revision is not completed So this issue will be rediscussed and confirmed during the next PSC meeting by end of 2015 before asking for approval by UNDP regional office
Through about a year of preparation application and assessment by end of Dec 2014 the state council announced that the Yinggeling NR was upgraded to national level Nature Reserve
The project is now looking into the possibility to support the Dongfang PNR to get international designation which is to be listed as an international site under the East Asian Australasian Flyway Programme as the first step to apply for NNR

description.narrative:
Operational MPAN is evident through
i Official recognition of Mangrove PA Network in Hainan PA system plans
ii Network coordination centre and training base established at Dongzhaigang NNR
iii All MPAN sites upload and update required site information to MPAN database according to agreed protocols

comment.narrative: Mangrove PAs are not networked lack of common management methods and standards limited information exchange

Operational MPAN evident through
i Official recognition of Mangrove PA Network in Hainan PA system plans
ii Network coordination centre and training base established at Dongzhaigang NNR
iii All MPAN sites upload and update required site information to MPAN database according to agreed protocols

In Dec 26 2014 the establishment meeting of the MWPAN was held in Haikou Directors from 10 project sites and the deputy director from Hainan Wild Animal and Plant Conservation Bureau which is responsible for Hainan PAs management attended the meeting The Declaration of the Network was discussed approved and signed by all member PAs on the meeting The declaration states that the Network will organize at least one meeting per year and a theme will be selected during the meeting which is to be the key focus for all member PAs for the year The theme for 2015 is biodiversity monitoring A timetable for monthly monitoring was agreed upon by all members
Necessary equipment including meeting room audiovisual equipment professional cameras for bird photography and computers etc were procured for the establishment of a training center in Dongzhaigang in the second half of 2014 After that a training event was organized in Dongzhaigang on species identification and monitoring in Nov 2014

description.narrative: Viable alternative options are demonstrated for target communities impacting mangrove resources at Dongzhaigang and Qinglangang that result in more sustainable resource use and include the equitable representation and involvement of women

comment.narrative: No assistance available from PA system to help local communities with economic opportunities
New comanagement structures are established that support and strengthen alternative livelihood options for target communities including equitable representation and involvement of women

The project made efforts to explore feasible alternative livelihood for local residents around NRs such as beeraising crabraising etc In Dongzhaigang 4 households were selected and trained to demonstrate beeraising

Livestock numbers reduced by 20 in Sandaohaizi wetland with economic burden to local people offset with alternative complementary livelihoods
Zoning of Liangheyuan NR reassessed and modified based on EHI surveys with illegal mining banned in corebuffer zones and grazing banned in core zones

Some of the herder families from Sandaohaizi are trying to change from herding to business livestock numbers reduced a little no statistic data yet The core zone of Liangheyuan NR is under strict management no human activities In addition of local herders the activities in buffer zone is reducing

description.narrative: The protection of wetland ecosystems through PA planning and management is enhanced in Altai Prefecture and XUAR through systemic legal and institutional capacity strengthening
Existence of effective legal framework for the Xinjiang PA system emplaced enhancing the conservation status of natural wetlands within the 35 PAs in Xinjiang UAR

No provincial level PA regulations w guidance for managers or clear stipulation of levels of authority
No sector plans that integrate PA objectives as well as biodiversity

At least two sectoral plans integrate PA objectives and biodiversity considerations such as water resources and agricultural bureaus
Regulation of Wetland Conservationhas been issued Carried out researches for 2 times in last year and provided primary suggestions on revising of PA Regulations

description.narrative: Existence of operational safeguard measures to protect wetland habitat and biodiversity from infrastructure placement and mining

comment.narrative:
EIA procedures are not adequately followed leading to undesirable impacts from infrastructure construction and mining
No legal obligation for postmining rehabilitation
No system for reporting malfeasance or through which to submit formal concerns or complaints or to make suggestions

EIA law is strictly enforced for construction and mining projects affecting wetland PAs with full participation of the wetland and PA management authorities
Clear standards are officially set up and enforced with minimum requirements for postextraction site restoration of mining sites
Hotline contact number operationalized also see the information platform above with referral system ie to other sectors in place

EIA laws enforced for construction and mining projects affecting wetland PAs ecosystem experts have chances to participate and provide suggestions on relevant sectors project which influence wetland habitat and biodiversity

description.narrative: Improved capacity scorecard SC scores of Forestry Department for participatory approaches in PA planning and management Q8 in SC PA staff competencies Q9 1619 in SC and public awareness and support Q21 in SC

comment.narrative:
Average score for Q89 1619 and 21 is 143
Most PA management plans not designed in participatory ways and not comprehensive and most PAs not managed collaboratively
Many Forestry and PA staff with inadequate skills for their jobs
Systematic monitoring and reporting systems not established limited availability or access to information necessary for PA operations incl biodiversity and socioeconomic development situations innear PAs

Average score for Q89 1619 and 21 is 24 at minimum through inter alia the following improvements
Majority of PAs in AMWL with updated and participatorially prepared management plans including comanagement components
More systematic staff training program designed and initiated
Accessible data and information sharing platform developed under supervision of XFD in support of PA management operationalised
Data sharing platform includes freeform categories for observations or information incl complaints submitted anonymously or by the public
This work expected to be done in 2016

description.narrative: Status of selected indicator species that are rare and threatened including inter alia Lynx lynx Ursus arctos arctos Alces alces Lepus timidus Tetrao parvirostris Bonasia bonasia Grus vipio Grus leucogeranus Aix galericulata Brachymystax lenok Astragalus mongholicus Chosenia arbutifolia

comment.narrative: Baseline survey of selected indicator species in Year 1 see methodological plan in Table 9
Key wildlife populations maintained or increasing

Indicator species listed are mostly very rare and not easy to quantify Recent surveys and photos confirm they are all still present
Model sites Duobukuer and Genhe have established qualitative diversity baseline of fish birds mammals herps and wetland plants EHI scores of those sites show stable or increasesin selected indicators since baseline surveys of 2013
5 additional sites have all now identified their own indicator species and established new baselines Deployment of automatic cameras will help add quantifiable basis for assessing indicator changes in future
Lynx lynx Very rare but occasionally seen Ursus arctos Rare and absent from most areas Alces alces widespread scarce but stable
Lepus timidus widespread commonly seen Tetrao parvirostris rare but still present Bonasia bonasia Common and often seen Grus vipio Grus leucogeranus seasonal visitors
Aix galericulatus common and breeding well Brachymystax lenox getting rare but still present
Astragalus mongholicus plant stable
Chosenia arbutifolia populations stable habitat OK

An expanded and more representative PA system has been planned and initiated at provincial level and that at the regional level will be done in 2016
Overall areas of PAs upgraded to national status increased by 71460 hectares and that upgraded to the provincial status by 106288 hectares
In Heilongjiang 3 new National Wetland Parks pilots were established increasing PA areas by 14856 ha 2 provincial nature reserves were newly designated covering an added protection area of 68612 hectares
In Inner Mongolia 1 natural reserve was upgraded to national level with a protection area of 56604 hectares and the area of newly upgraded provincial NR is 37676 hectares

description.narrative: Threats reduced by mainstreaming biodiversity conservation and the PA system within the sectoral and development planning frameworks indicated by effective intersectoral coordination and plans incorporating biodiversity conservation measures

comment.narrative:
No intersectoral coordination mechanism for biodiversity conservation and PAs exist at Landscape level
Sectoral plans do not include adequate measures for biodiversity conservation
12th 5 year plan includes chapter for biodiversity conservation but needs mainstreaming throughout

Intersectoral Groups for coordinating biodiversity conservation functioning and steering the process at landscape level
At least 2 sectoral plans among forestry tourism agriculture water mining integrate biodiversity conservation measures including clear safeguard measures in sector practices
13th 5 yearPlan recognises clear linkage between biodiversity and PAs and sectoral development and includes PA and biodiversityrelated targets

The Project Coordination Groups PCG of Heilongjiang and Inner Mongolia FMAs established comprising focal points from relevant sectorsdivisions including conservation science water environment silviculture tourism planning industry agriculture livestock and fishery finance communications as well as the demonstration site FMB and representatives of local communities the first meeting held respectively to advise the project and promote mainstreaming of biodiversity and protected areas into key development plans
Plans incorporating biodiversity conservation measures formulated or drafted within the reporting period include 1 HJ 1 Ecological Conservation and Improvement Plan of Heilongjiang Province 20142020 promulgated by the Forestry Department of Heilongjiang provincial government Plan of Building Daxinganling Eco Civilization Years 20132020 Plan of Building Eco Civilization 2013 2020 in Daxinganling and Daxinganling LowEmission Development Plan by the Administrative Office of Development and Reform Commission of Heilongjiang 13th5year Plan of the Forest Group Company Plan of Building Eco Civilization Demonstration Areas in Daxinganling Years 2014 2018 Programme of Building Forest Ecological Conservation and Building National Demonstration PAs in Daxinganling Heilongjiang by the Forestry Group Company Implementation Plan of Daxinganling Ecological Conservation and Improvement by the Provincial Administrative Office Moreover Nanwenhe NNR and other 7 NNRs have been listed in Heilongjiang Provincial Wetland Ecotourism Plan by Provincial Tourism Bureau 2 in IM provisions of Improvement of Forestry Eco System Building Biooriginated Economic System etc have been integrated into the Notice on National Forestry Reform by the Forest Industry Group Forest Authority Biological conservation eg wildlife flora and fauna protection will be integrated in
Inner Mongolia Forest 13th 5year Plan which has been formulating since late 2014 In April 2015 Inner Mongolia Forest Industry Group Forest Authority has been approved by the National Development and Reform Commission and other departments as a Demonstration Area for Eco protection and construction thanks to the advices and support of the PCGs

description.narrative: Reduction in illegal incidents within the PAs poaching illegal harvesting etc despite improved activity of rangers

comment.narrative:
Inner Mongolia section average of 2908 administrative cases and 79 criminal cases 2009 10
Heilongjiang section average of 95 administrative cases and 20 criminal cases 2010 11
10 decrease from the baseline for each province section despite improved rangering

Inner Mongolia section average of 37 administrative cases and 0 criminal cases 2014 Heilongjiang section average of 4 administrative cases and 0 criminal cases 2014
In 2014 the Heilongjiang region assigned more than 3700 peopletimes and more than 1350 vehiclestimes to inspect criminal cases related to biodiversity conservation on the market restaurants and other establishments inspected 680 sites Besides a total of 118 unauthorized visitorsvillagers were expelled from the PAs more than 3500 passing vehicles were inspected 870 hunting gear were impounded more than 170 live birds released 8 wildlife and wild animal products were impounded and 4 wildlife cases were uncovered
In the Inner Mongolia area there was no criminal case found in PAs during this period thanks to the strengthened enforcement of relevant laws regulations and policies by both the authorities and local people that has been greatly promoted and supported by the project For example Hanma National Reserve strengthened the monitoring and publicity developed relevant work processes systems and management practices developed a wildlife patrol monitoring system and carried out regular inspection supervision and guidance of the implementation A total of 30 automatic infrared cameras have been emplaced for effective monitoring in populous areas of wildlife 16 additional wildlife monitoring sites have been established Furthermore several special reports and articles had been published for raising the public awareness At the Erguna NNR 5 times patrolling were carried out into the mountain areas removed 2 sets of hunting gear evicted 24 persontimes of people illegally entered into the protected areas for construction exploration hunting and fishing purposes

comment.narrative: N/A

- From March 25 to March 27, 2015,a delegation of the National Forestry Bureau and representatives of Beijing Forestry University, University of Aeronautics and Astronautics and biomass energy companies visited Alukerqinqi, Chifeng city of Inner Mongolia for research of development of the forestry biomass energy industry. - On April 3, 2015, a seminar of industry, academic studies and scientific researches was held between Dalian Nationalities University and the company, during which President Liu Yubin, experts from the university and the company representatives concluded the proceeding cooperation and discussed the next-stage cooperation plan. - “Science and Technology Innovation and Development Forum for Xinjiang Biomass Energy Forest Industry” was held in Urumqi, Xinjiang on June 10, 2015. After that participants visited the demonstration site where they discussed the ways to improve the base construction mode and technical route. More than 800 base construction personnel participated the training. - On August 31, 2015, the biomass energy product forum was held to discuss product RD and equipment manufacturing. - On September 8, 2015,a project forum was held, in which the UNDP China representative DCD Mr. Patrick Haverman, Zhang Weidong,officials of CICETE cooperation and President Li Tie communicated onthe next-stage development and mission and discussedprospective cooperation. - From December 11 to December 25, 2015, 15,000 mu of plant (20% are poplar, 40% are sea buckthorn, 40% are xanthoceras sorbifolia) were planted, 20 km of sand stone road were paved, 20-km high-voltage lines were installed and 19 motor- pumped wells were dug. - In 2015, 50,000 mu of land were leveled, 40,000 mu of xanthoceras sorbifolia, hippophae rhamnoides, xinjiang poplar and haloxylon were planted, 52 motor pumped wells were dug, 38 km of roads were paved, 38 km of high voltage lines are installed, and 40,000 mu of land were equipped with drip irrigation system. - Automatic

Supplementary support for achieving convention objectives and publication and dissemination of the 3NC report. 7. Supporting China Biennial update report completed and submitting to the UNFCCC in order to prepare the BUR.

1. After the project inception workshop, the research group pf this sub-contractor has understood the data requirement, potential data providers. 2. The research group of this sub-contractor has determined the methodology of industrial processes. and the group has coordinated with association experts of industrial processes for cooperation, and is now collecting activity level data and emission factors data. 3. The research group have finished data collecting of animal amounts on national and provincial level. 4. The existing China's GHG inventory database was analyzed to find out characteristics and shortcomings. Inventory management and construction experience from 8 developed countries, 7 developing countries and some domestic provinces have been investigated. Preliminary system scheme . 5. This activity has completed the website for the third national communication promotion and put it online on November 30, 2015. 6. Foundational information of the national circumstances, impacts and adaption of climate change in China, on the proposed mitigation policies and measures in China, and on the latest developments on climate system observations and climate research on the basis of the results of the activities in Components 1 to 5 are being collected. 7. A workshop was held in January, 2016 to discuss the outline. 11 experts were invited to review the outline.

comment.narrative: 1. the understanding od domestic and abroad users on LED enterprises in China is weak, especially on the energy efficiency situation, quality of the products, and technological levels, etc. 2. There is lack of good channels in disseminating the best practices of technology innovations for Chinese LED enterprises. In the existing technology innovation completion and relevant public promotion campaigns, LED has never been involved as an independent sector. 3. Energy management of government agencies has been listed in the important items on energy conservation of China. Obviously the problem that lacking of the competent personnel on energy conservation in government agencies has caused concern, 4. Although a pert of the personnel of government agencies have taken the training of the knowledge on energy conservation, the systematic training pf policies and regulations interpretation and practice capability are badly needed at present. 5. The understanding about the development of LED technologies in other countries is weak, especially the study of advanced LED technologies through study tours abroad and trainings inside China is very weak.
1.Construction for "environment friendly demonstration plant" 2. Energy Conservation Training materials

1. according to the project document, Klite attended one lighting exhibitions in Guangzhou and plans to attend another two in Hong King in 2015. 2. Energy conservation for government agencies has ked the whole society to the direction of energy-efficiency and a conservation-oriented society construction. We are cooperating with CQC on designing and conducting a series of training activities for the public sectors to promote the levels on energy conservation of government agencies, regulate the behabior of energy using and speed the capacity improvement for energy conservation on the current bases up to realize the goals set in the 12th Five year plan. 3. Building technology capacity and initiating demonstration projects are always important tools for China to promote the development of certain sectors. In recent years, with the policy supports from the government and the efforts from the enterprises, progresses have been made in technology capacity building, however, they are still insufficient. Therefore, in this project, a number of activities have been organized in order to promote the building of technology capacity, and initiate the demonstration projects.

description.narrative: The PIP consists of the project preparatory activities such as: (1) Conduct of studies and surveys to come up with the pertinent data and information that are required to verify and confirm the earlier identified baseline projects on, and barriers to, the widespread application of energy efficient green logistics techniques and practices in the logistics industry; (2) Conduct of a logical framework analysis (LFA) mainly to verify and firm up the project planning matrix (PPM) or results framework (log frame); (3) Identification and assessment of demonstrations for the manufacturing and application of improved SSL products; (4) Detailed design of the project components and activities (includes evaluation and analyses of the results of, and data/information derived from, the studies and surveys conducted for use in the design of specific project activities; basic design of demonstration projects, estimation of potential energy savings and CO2 emission reduction, project activities budgeting, etc.); (5) Conduct of stakeholder and project partner coordination meetings (e.g., demonstration hosts and co-financers), and establishment of the appropriate project implementation and management arrangements; (6) Preparation of the UNDP-GEF Project Document (ProDoc) and GEF CEO Endorsement Request (CER) Document based on the GEF-approved project concept, i.e., GEF-approved PIF (Annex 1); and, (7) Finalization of the ProDoc and CER Document. The final output of this PIP is the approved UNDP-GEF Project Document and GEF CEO Endorsement Request Document.

comment.narrative:
As part of Denmark’s focus on South-South Cooperation, to enable better and more coherent cooperation between China and countries in Africa, in particular around the promotion of the UN’s Sustainable Energy for All initiative(SE4ALL), UNDP China has been funded to develop this project document. The project proposal has been developed with the Zambian Ministry of Mines, Energy and Water Development, China’s Ministry of Science and Technology and the advice of stakeholders from government, the private sector and research institutions in Zambia and China. The project aims to support the access to electricity for rural communities in Zambia. It will do so through the creation of an enabling environment to up-scale renewable energy technology deployment. This includes removing market barriers for introduction of improved renewable energy technologies and the strengthening of South – South Cooperation between Zambia and China.
1.1 Draft review report of the implementation of policies and legislation for rural electrification using off-grid technologies exists. Current legislation ineffective and incomplete. 1.2 Financial mechanisms insufficient (baseline: UNDP scoping mission to Zambia 2013) 2.1 Testing and training centers not equipped and functional (baseline: UNDP scoping mission to Zambia 2013) 2.2 Capacity gaps exist (baseline: UNDP scoping mission to Zambia 2013) 3.1 Knowledge gaps exist (baseline: UNDP / MOST dialogue 2013) 3.2 Chinese Center for South-South Cooperation within MOST does not exist 4.1 Project management structures not in place.
Zambia has the second largest potential for solar power in the world, currently virtually unused, and an abundance of rivers and water resources in the rural areas. Building on this potential, solar- and hydro power are identified as the most appropriate renewable energy technologies for Zambia and thus consistent with the Chinese development experience.
